title: How to Get Rid of Bagworms

steps.title: Begin looking for bagworms during the winter or early spring.
steps.content: Begin looking for bagworms during the winter or early spring. Bagworm egg sacks are brown and one and a half to two inches (3.8 to 5 cm) long. They are covered with dead needles, so they appear more noticeable in contrast to the green deciduous needles at this time. [1] X Research source Bagworm sacks can be very hard to find because they look like pine cones. Look through your pinecones to find variations that may be bagworms.

steps.title: Sweep and rake under trees regularly to get rid of fallen egg sacks.
steps.content: Sweep and rake under trees regularly to get rid of fallen egg sacks. Don't put the debris in the compost, where the larvae can live. Place them in sealed plastic bags in your trashcan. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Notice areas of dead pine needles or branches.
steps.content: Notice areas of dead pine needles or branches. If your tree has begun to turn brown, the bagworms might have killed it already. You will want to try a last effort to rid your entire garden of the worms, so that they don't spread to other trees.

steps.title: Observe new places the bagworms may live.
steps.content: Observe new places the bagworms may live. Their silks are transported by the wind. Anywhere the wind blows in your yard is a potential new spot for the moths and a great place to look.

steps.title: Fill a plastic bucket with a mixture of warm water and dish soap.
steps.content: Fill a plastic bucket with a mixture of warm water and dish soap. Mix it well.

steps.title: Put on garden gloves and bring a small pair of clippers to aid you in removing the bagworms entirely.
steps.content: Put on garden gloves and bring a small pair of clippers to aid you in removing the bagworms entirely. Clippers will remove all traces of the bagworm threads, so that it's harder for new bagworms to find their way into the tree.

steps.title: Lift branches, clip off bagworm egg sacks and drop them into the bucket of soapy water.
steps.content: Lift branches, clip off bagworm egg sacks and drop them into the bucket of soapy water. Make sure they are submerged fully. [3] X Trustworthy Source Missouri Botanical Garden Oldest botanical garden in the U.S. and center for botanical research and science education Go to source

steps.title: Dump the soaked bagworms into a sealed plastic sack and throw them in your dumpster.
steps.content: Dump the soaked bagworms into a sealed plastic sack and throw them in your dumpster.

steps.title: Repeat this procedure every fall, winter and early spring to reduce bagworm populations before the eggs hatch.
steps.content: Repeat this procedure every fall, winter and early spring to reduce bagworm populations before the eggs hatch. You will reduce the amount of pesticide you need to use if you do a thorough job of handpicking the egg sacks.

steps.title: Plan to treat bagworms with insecticide in May.
steps.content: Plan to treat bagworms with insecticide in May. This is when they hatch and are at their most vulnerable. In some areas they hatch in early June. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Look for a small, worm-like head poking out of the top of the sack.
steps.content: Look for a small, worm-like head poking out of the top of the sack. However, they often get spooked back into their sack if they are startled. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Purchase an insecticide such as Dipel or Thuricide.
steps.content: Purchase an insecticide such as Dipel or Thuricide. They contain bacillus thuringiensis, a bacteria that is deadly to young bagworms. If you have many trees affected by bagworms, it can be expensive to thoroughly kill the bagworms with insecticide. Orthene, Talstar and Tempo are other insecticides that have been effective in killing newly-hatched bagworms. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Put the insecticide in a sprayer.
steps.content: Put the insecticide in a sprayer. Thoroughly wet the leaves and needles of the trees that can be affected. Beware when spraying insecticide around pets and small children. [7] X Research source Consider cordoning off the area just after you spray.

steps.title: Spray insecticide in late May, June and early July.
steps.content: Spray insecticide in late May, June and early July. This is when it can kill young larvae. Stop by late July and August when the bagworms are resilient and the insecticide no longer works. [8] X Research source Once September and early October begin, the adult bagworms begin fertilizing their eggs. You should begin the process of handpicking the egg sacks at this time. Adult male bagworms are moths with black wings and brown spots. They die after fertilization. Female bagworms remain inside the sack in their larval state.
